title: Accurately Value Your Investment Properties
excerpt: Understanding your property's current value is essential for making informed investment decisions, managing risk, and optimizing returns. This guide covers DIY valuation methods, working with real estate professionals, and formal appraisals.

content.text: Knowing the current value of your investment properties is crucial for tracking ROI, ensuring proper insurance coverage, verifying property tax assessments, and making decisions about refinancing or selling. The fair market value reflects what a knowledgeable buyer would pay in today’s market.
Investors can estimate property value using three main approaches, each suited to different property types and scenarios.

items: Market Approach: Compare recent sales of similar properties (comps) to estimate value. Adjust for differences in features, then calculate an average price per square foot.
Income Approach: Best for larger multifamily or commercial properties. Calculate net operating income (NOI) and divide by the market cap rate to estimate value.
Cost Approach: Useful for unique or new properties. Add land value to the depreciated replacement cost of improvements to determine total value.

content.text: If you lack experience or market knowledge, consider consulting a real estate agent or broker. Agents can provide a Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) for free, while brokers may offer a more detailed Broker’s Opinion of Value (BOV) for a fee. These reports use market data to estimate value and can be helpful for informal assessments or tax disputes.

A licensed appraiser can provide a formal appraisal, which is often required for refinancing, buying, or selling. Though more costly, appraisals are considered the most accurate method and are typically required by lenders to confirm property value.

items: Regularly assess your property’s value to inform investment decisions.
Choose the valuation method that best fits your property type and needs.
Leverage professional expertise when necessary, especially for complex or high-value assets.
